Award.AwardTitle: Gate-Modulated Charge Density-Dependent Physics of Low-Dimensional Inorganic Semiconductors in Organic Multilayers
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: Topological insulators, such as bismuth selenides and bismuth tellurides, are materials with inherent conductive states near their surfaces. This research project utilizes multifunctional organic layers to control the surface chemical potentials and bonding interactions in these materials, introducing sufficient charge density to reveal atomic and structural features that determine the surface conductive states. The layered structures are used to encapsulate thin films of topological insulators to reach a high charge density at low applied voltages, maximize dielectric strength, and tune local band energies. Local electric fields are designed to be as large as those in ionic liquids presently employed, but in a much better defined geometry. Terahertz magneto-optical polarimetry will provide a powerful probe to determine scattering rates, charge densities, and band masses for several parallel transport channels simultaneously. The research offers opportunities to observe physical phenomena such as correlated electron transport, spin polarized conduction in topological insulators, and unconventional superconductivity and charge-density waves. It can lead to new ways of controlling chalcogenide-organic interfaces in general.

Non-technical Description: There is a great interest in materials that can manipulate electrical and magnetic signals with high energy efficiency, and that can store and process information more and more rapidly. This research project concerns the study of a new class of mineral-like materials that have a special ability to conduct electricity very effectively at certain locations. A new way to package and switch these materials using plastic-like media is developed. This method is expected to avoid some of the complications of previous methods and allow better understanding of the factors that control the electrical and magnetic behavior of the materials. The result of this work will help to create new possibilities for designing future computers and data management systems. Graduate and undergraduate students in this project synthesize materials and perform characterizations of materials and devices, acquiring a broad technical basis for diversified science and technology employment. These activities also form the basis of fabrication and characterization modules in undergraduate materials science and materials physics laboratory courses. Students from Western High School, a public, largely minority and low-income girl's school in Baltimore City, also participate in the research as part of an after-school program, and ultimately serve as ambassadors to feeder middle schools as well.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electronics technologies depend on materials that behave in different ways when electrical force (voltage) is applied to them.  Some materials contain electrically charged particles, like electrons, that can move easily, creating electrical current when voltage is applied.   Such materials are called "conductors".  Metals are common examples of conductors.  Other materials, called insulators, resist the movement of any charged particles when voltage is applied.  The rubber coating around wires is an insulator.   A third class of materials, called "semiconductors", can be switched between insulator and conductor states under different conditions.  Silicon is the most well known semiconductor.  Its ability to be switched back and forth allows computers to make logical decisions, perform calulcations, and process data.

This project explored ways to control the conductor and insulator states of a distinct set of materials, called "topological insulators", that have the interesting property that they are insulators on the inside, but conductors at their surfaces. While this situation could be achieved by coating a metal on top of an insulator, different technological possiblities are opened by having the arrangement be a fundamental attribute of a single material.  For example, there could be new, faster, and more power-efficient ways to carry out the logic functions of computers.  There could also be new ways to make sensors to detect changes in the surrounding area, such as changes in magnetic fields or gases in the atmosphere, that could be important for security applications.  

The team included experts in making topological insulators, applying other materials on them to control their electronic properties, and measuring the effects of applying the additional materials.  The topological insulator we used is a compound of the elements bismuth and selenium. The two kinds of additional materials used were organic solids (made mostly from carbon, as are the compounds of living things) and plastics related to the coatings of nonstick cooking pans.  The organic solids had the property that they could extract some of the electrons from the topological insulators, making the insides more "insulating" so the conducting properties of the surfaces could be made more apparent.   The plastics also had this property, but the property came from a special process of applying static electricity to the plastics after they were coated onto the topological insulators.

The project resulted in the creation of some of the highest quality topological insulators in the world--the bismuth-selenium compounds were very pure and free of cracks and other defects that would make the electrical properties difficult to observer.   The use of the organic materials made the electrical properties very close to those of "perfect" topological insulators--the insides were almost completely insulating while the electrons could still move very easily with voltage applied.  The ways that the electrical properties were controlled had the advantage that the controlling function did not require extra wiring or continuous powering, so if devices were made of the samples of this project, they could be easier to connect to other devices and would use less power when they were operated.

Besides the technology achievements, this project supported the advancement of science and engineering students at different levels.   For example, at least three graduate students will have completed their Doctoral degrees by working on this project and becoming trained in cutting edge electronic materials science.   Also, four high school students that are members of underrepresented groups in science and engineering were supported on this project to learn about new energy conversion and chemical sensing technologies.
